Let me think about the steps in C code:

First, read N and M.

Let me outline the steps in code:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

int main() {
    int N, M;
    scanf("%d %d", &N, &M);
    // Read array A of size N
    long long *A = malloc(N * sizeof(long long));
    for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
        scanf("%lld", &A[i]);
    }

    // Compute the cumulative remainders array
    // Create B array of size N+1: B[0] = 0, B[1..N] = A[0..N-1]
    long long *B = malloc((N+1)*sizeof(long long));
    B[0] = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; i++) {
        B[i] = A[i-1];
    }

    // Compute mod_B array (each element mod M)
    int *mod_B = malloc((N+1)*sizeof(int));
    for (int i = 0; i <= N; i++) {
        mod_B[i] = B[i] % M;
    }

    // Compute cumulative sum array cum_sum
    long long *cum_sum = malloc((N+1)*sizeof(long long));
    cum_sum[0] = mod_B[0];
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; i++) {
        cum_sum[i] = cum_sum[i-1] + mod_B[i];
    }

    // Compute cum_remainders array (each element mod M)
    int *cum_remainders = malloc((N+1)*sizeof(int));
    for (int i = 0; i <= N; i++) {
        cum_remainders[i] = cum_sum[i] % M;
    }

    // Count the frequency of each remainder
    int *count = calloc(M, sizeof(int)); // Initialize to 0
    for (int i = 0; i <= N; i++) {
        count[cum_remainders[i]]++;
    }

    // Compute combinations
    long long combinations = 0;
    for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
        if (count[i] >= 2) {
            combinations += (count[i] * (count[i] - 1)) / 2;
        }
    }

    // Free allocated memory
    free(A);
    free(B);
    free(mod_B);
    free(cum_sum);
    free(cum_remainders);
    free(count);

    // Compute second part's result
    int second_result = (combinations == 0) ? 1 : 0;

    // Output the second_result
    printf("%d\n", second_result);

    return 0;
}

4. For each group of size k, add k*(k-1)/2 to the total combinations. 

This way, we don't need an array of size M. 

This is a better approach for C. 

So modifying the code accordingly. 

Let me outline the steps:

After computing the cum_remainders array (of size N+1), we can sort it. 

Then, initialize a counter variable, and iterate through the sorted array:

Initialize current_remainder to the first element, count = 1. 

Then for each next element:

if equal to current_remainder → increment count. 

else → add count*(count-1)/2 to combinations, then reset current_remainder and count. 

At the end, add the last count's contribution. 

This way, we can count the frequencies without needing an array of size M. 

This is feasible. 

So the code would be:

// After computing cum_remainders array of size N+1 (type long long?)

Wait, cum_remainders[i] is cum_sum[i] mod M. 

Wait, cum_sum[i] is a long long, mod M gives a value between 0 and M-1. 

Thus, the cum_remainders can be stored as an array of integers (assuming M is up to 2^31-1). 

Wait, but if M is up to 1e18, then the remainder can be up to 1e18-1, which won't fit in an int (which is 32 bits). 

Hmm, so perhaps we need to use long long for the cum_remainders array. 

Yes. 

So, in code:

// Compute cum_remainders array (each element mod M)
long long *cum_remainders = malloc((N+1)*sizeof(long long));
for (int i = 0; i <= N; i++) {
    cum_remainders[i] = cum_sum[i] % M;
}

Then, sort this array. 

Sorting an array of N+1 elements is manageable even for large N (assuming N is up to 1e5 or so). 

Then, after sorting, count the consecutive duplicates. 

So the code for counting combinations would be:

long long combinations = 0;
if (N+1 == 0) { // but N is at least 1? Probably not needed. }
qsort(cum_remainders, N+1, sizeof(long long), compare);

long long current = cum_remainders[0];
int count = 1;
for (int i = 1; i <= N; i++) {
    if (cum_remainders[i] == current) {
        count++;
    } else {
        combinations += (count * (count -1)) / 2;
        current = cum_remainders[i];
        count = 1;
    }
}
// Add the last group
combinations += (count * (count -1)) / 2;

This requires a compare function for qsort. 

The compare function would be:

int compare(const void *a, const void *b) {
    return (*(long long*)a - *(long long*)b);
}

Wait, but in C, the subtraction can overflow. To avoid that, better to use:

int compare(const void *a, const void *b) {
    long long x = *(long long*)a;
    long long y = *(long long*)b;
    if (x < y) return -1;
    if (x > y) return 1;
    return 0;
}

But in C, the qsort compare function must return an int. So the above is better. 

Thus, the code would need to include this compare function. 

Putting it all together, the C code would be:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

int compare(const void *a, const void *b) {
    long long x = *(long long*)a;
    long long y = *(long long*)b;
    if (x < y) return -1;
    else if (x > y) return 1;
    else return 0;
}

int main() {
    int N, M;
    scanf("%d %d", &N, &M);
    // Read array A of size N
    long long *A = malloc(N * sizeof(long long));
    for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
        scanf("%lld", &A[i]);
    }

    // Create B array of size N+1: B[0] = 0, B[1..N] = A[0..N-1]
    long long *B = malloc((N+1)*sizeof(long long));
    B[0] = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; i++) {
        B[i] = A[i-1];
    }

    // Compute mod_B array (each element mod M)
    long long *mod_B = malloc((N+1)*sizeof(long long));
    for (int i = 0; i <= N; i++) {
        mod_B[i] = B[i] % M;
    }

    // Compute cumulative sum array cum_sum
    long long *cum_sum = malloc((N+1)*sizeof(long long));
    cum_sum[0] = mod_B[0];
    for (int i = 1; i <= N; i++) {
        cum_sum[i] = cum_sum[i-1] + mod_B[i];
    }

    // Compute cum_remainders array (each element mod M)
    long long *cum_remainders = malloc((N+1)*sizeof(long long));
    for (int i = 0; i <= N; i++) {
        cum_remainders[i] = cum_sum[i] % M;
    }

    // Sort the cum_remainders array
    qsort(cum_remainders, N+1, sizeof(long long), compare);

    // Count the combinations
    long long combinations = 0;
    if (N+1 == 0) { // shouldn't happen since N is at least 1?
        // handle error
    } else {
        long long current = cum_remainders[0];
        int count = 1;
        for (int i = 1; i <= N; i++) {
            if (cum_remainders[i] == current) {
                count++;
            } else {
                combinations += (count * (count -1)) / 2;
                current = cum_remainders[i];
                count = 1;
            }
        }
        // Add the last group
        combinations += (count * (count -1)) / 2;
    }

    // Free allocated memory
    free(A);
    free(B);
    free(mod_B);
    free(cum_sum);
    free(cum_remainders);

    // Compute second part's result
    int second_result = (combinations == 0) ? 1 : 0;

    // Output the second_result
    printf("%d\n", second_result);

    return 0;
}

Wait, but in the code above, the mod_B array is computed as B[i] mod M. 

Wait, B is the array [0, A[0], A[1], ...], so mod_B[i] is B[i] mod M. 

Yes. 

This should handle large M values.
